comment_text: Loving all the discussion on this! Indeed, the size of my figurine may have confounded the first experiment (in the original design, their 'person' was much smaller, but this is the LEGO I had to work with at home and it hadn't occurred to me). I'm also finding it fascinating how big a role language/word use in the puzzles has impacted people differently, with words like "switching" having a different connotation to some people - I hadn't totally thought of that before! Regardless, hope you can appreciate the idea (and the research paper if you have a chance to look at it, in the description notes). It changed my perspective on decision making a lot, and hopefully it will have an impact on some of you as well :)

4:17
If you want to take of a segment and not want to delete the line, you can change it into a comment, and then it wouldn't be active, but still there, and it wouldn't change anything.
If someone found an error and kept on writing things to solve it, well they aren't likely to be the best... In coding there's this process- testing, which you go one by one line by line to find out where the bug comes from, many times it could be just a misspelling😅
There are many ways to write one thing, and it's important to remember as a programer, that you have the right to change the code in all aspects.
And if there's a segment of code you don't want to be active and keep it for later, you can keep it for later. :-)

I've built a lot of Lego in my life, so the solution with removing that block never occurred to me, because the Lego man wouldn't fit under the roof if I did that. But ironically, removing that piece was my first thought, the second was, oh shit no we can't, the Lego man wouldn't fit. So my solution to the problem was putting a block on top of the roof, right above the red piece, so the roof was between the one you were supposed to move and the new one. That would help in real life if you should even out the weight. If you put too much weight at the edge, it would tip. But, putting weight on top of the place where its most stable, will make it possible to put more weight on the edges too. Think of a table top thats not attached to anything, it just balances on one block underneath. To make it more stable, the solution is to put more weight where it's already stable. Of course, you could just remove the piece under the table and just put the table top on the floor, but it wouldn't be a table then, would it?

Also.. Being a person who's been bullied for years, and learned that I'm never good enough for anyone, I've always wondered what I could do with myself to be more perfect. What should I add? I've already done that, that's not what I figured out from this video. But it's interesting that many of us automatically think the solution is to add something.

Oh jeez. I didn't think of this at all in terms of a real situation, only a puzzle, and that's both what threw me and what pulled me back on track. My typical experience with structural logic puzzles is "arrange these additional pieces to fit within the established structure" or very clearly stated/shown "move things to the right places, in the right order and/or with these restrictions on movement." I'm not currently recalling any subtractive puzzles I've come across. So even though I did have the fleeting thought "it'd be easiest to just take that one brick out," I immediately dismissed it with the assumption that it wouldn't be allowed.

Further description made it seem like the next obvious answer had to be too obvious (especially since you explicitly mention it), so maybe there was supposed to be some physics trick, and as mentioned, the "you get a dollar if you do it, but each brick costs you 10 cents" sounds like "you want to add as few bricks as possible," and if zero isn't an option, there has to be a way to do it with just one - but I'm still thinking there has to be some trick instead of the obvious 1-brick answer.

It was all the other examples that completed it, specifically with the requirement that everything be vertically and horizontally symmetrical. The only ways to achieve that without adding multiple blocks were to either reposition what's there, or remove the extras creating the problem in the first place.

That said, yeah, the proposed explanations for the wider phenomenon sound about right to me. ^^

All these puzzles require understanding the rules, and without a clear explanation it's almost impossible not to assume that the minimum possible ruleset is in place. I noticed I also automatically didn't even consider undoing your work, because you went through the effort of setting up the puzzle, which presumably meant that the way it was displayed were the constraints I was working with. lol I'm only writing this comment now because you almost exactly explained my thoughts on why I came to my solution, after explaining that the rule set wasn't what I thought it was. Not explaining the rules well comes off more as an intentional trick than a psychological bias, even if I made a conscious decision to follow the rules as they appeared.

I feel like, from an evolutionary perspective, it makes sense to want to add stuff. Usually it takes less effort to fill in the gaps rather than remove them entirely. We want to use what we have, and build something on top of that, like how we learn the basics of math early on, and slowly build on top of that. Subtracting something means that what was done previously was a waste of time and resources, so we don't like to do it. In a lot of these examples, we assume things like the overall size of the Lego structure exists for a reason.

For the symmetric green block, count deleting blocks as an action and adding blocks as an action, then, moving them are also actions.

Deleting the square is 4 actions, yet, moving the three green squares that are next to the one already in the corner to the other corners do no add or subtract blocks and count as 3 actions (the one in the corner you needn’t move). So, you get symmetry for less cost.

As a programmer that teaches coding and creates things for non-coders, I prefer adding comments and breaking code into longer bits (several steps allow for easier to understand error catching for new people), but I'm often yelled at by people who are programmers of specific languages who write for other programmers of specific languages for having too much code, too many comments, and not using "efficient" enough code to match how they were taught. It really depends on your goals and audience whether it's better to add or remove parts of something. Same goes with accessibility add-ons (sometimes adding accessible options seem like too much to people who don't use them, but if there's not a way to include the accessibility in the original, keep it) and educational materials (could we all just learn from words on a page? Yes. Would we learn well or be motivated to continue, though?)

Case of the lego brick structure: The figurine would clip into the top plate if the block was removed, so only a person who disregards consistency of reality would say that removing that block is a valid answer. And while the figurine could bend somewhat to accomodate for this lost space, it is not made clear that it is valid to do so in this system. (In addition, in reality you can not remove an integral part of the structure like that... imagine just cutting out a concrete block or wooden beam like that... the resulting structure is always going to be of worse structural quality in the end.) Extremely bad example.
Case of the squares: You said to "switch" the squares... This is ambiguous in that you might mean that you can switch the state of the squares (say white is off and coloured is on)... or you could have meant that the there is a constraint that you may only switch the places of squares, therefore not allowing the ratio of coloured to white squares change. Fairly bad example.
Case of the golf course: What in the ever loving f**k does "improving" the golf course mean? That you could put it in with a single put? That it would be more difficult and challenging, hence more enjoyable to play the course? That it would only be a sterile golf course? Or perhaps you mean my subjective opinion on how to make the best golf course there is? Insanely bad example...

You can't mislead and leave out information, and then act in some way surprised that people answered in a "nonoptimal" way from your point of view.

At least give your viewers a chance to deduce the optimal answer by giving out all of the relevant information - In case of the lego example, not use a lego figurine, in case of the squares, explain that switching means switching the state of a square on or off and in case of the golf course... well... you can't fix the golf course example because your notion of "improving" the golf course is removing the obstacles, which is completely subjective and not a consensus on how to objectively improve a golf course... because such an objective reality does not exist.

Please think through your examples better in the future. Manipulating your viewers into being surprised at something you want to explain, by setting them up to "fail" to prove your point, is an asshole move... Many people enjoy brain-teasers, and none of these examples were a fair brain-teaser to begin with.

And in case these were not your original examples (having continued to watch, it appears this is the case indeed...), then sorry for being harsh on you... but then try to find better examples next time...

I have some serious criticisms for this video. But before I get into them I want to make it clear that I am a huge fan of this channel and have been for MANY years. The first and most obvious was already addressed in your pinned comment, was the language used in the prompt of the first problems asking the viewer if they could "switch" the blocks, how would they make them symmetrical. Also, the height of the doll, but I get that you were working with what you had. I think this is ironic considering the point is that how the choice of language determines how participants solve problems.

Second is to say that, regarding subtracting as a solution, people in the neurodiversity and disability communities have been trying to make the point about removing barriers, both literal and metaphorical, for decades. Its the needlessly complex systems that often hamper the those of us that are the the most disadvantaged in society. It feels very similar to the way that quarantine taught us that many of the accommodations that these two groups were asking for such as working from home and curbside delivery were not needed until the rest of society decided it was.
Lastly, you make that point that its often the case that subtracting from a situation can be a valuable way to solve problems, decrease financial burden, reduce stress, and not play into the capitalist mindset. Then you go on to promote a subscription service. Don't get me wrong, Skill Share seems like a really neat thing. As someone who loves learning as a hobby I've often thought about getting a subscription. However, I feel like it made the message of simplifying very disingenuous and the sponsorship seem very counterintuitive.
I hope that these points will be heard and taken in good faith as they were written. Again, I love your channel and I can't tell you how much I've learned from you over the years. Keep doin what you guys do. I think you're amazing.

Is it just me, or does this seem really trivial? In most cases of our lives, we can't just remove things (they were made for some purpose). So it's obvious if we have to modify something, first thing we think about is adding something. And only if we invest a lot of time and energy to the task (enough to gain in depth knowledge of the whole design), we can safely know that we can remove something.
Maybe it's because I'm a software engineer and face these problems daily (add or remove), but I think this is the same as asking: "Do you want to carry 10kg rock or 1kg rock?" You'll obviously choose the lighter one, just because it's easier.

tl;dr; you need a lot more effort and time to SAFELY remove something than to add, so it's obvious we choose adding first.

The main reason that people will think of "adding" is for the simple reason that you tell them to.
You say you get $1 if you solve it and subtract 10 cents for every block used. That means that you need to use addition to solve the puzzle.
How much did you earn with your solution? $1.10? That would mean you earn more than what you just said that you could. Which invalidates that solution.
You also primed people to think about adding blocks, when you spelled it out where you could put them.
You also didn't mention that it was possible to remove the support block, it is more logical to think that you try to keep the roof from collapsing by adding more support to it.
Since removing the only support it has, will definitely make it collapse. Unless you would support the roof while doing so, but then you would have solved the puzzle by adding while trying to solve the puzzle by subtracting. There is simply no way that you can solve the puzzle by subtracting without solving the puzzle by adding. (unless blowing up the support and hoping for the roof to fall down in a nice manner, is something you see as a solution.)
The reason why people didn't think about removing stuff, is because it is simply not a solution in real life.
(also, the Lego man is too tall for your solution, so your solution didn't work from the getgo.)

In the second puzzle, you said the word switch, which a lot of people will have interpreted as switching a green block with a white block. (since the previous puzzle was also about blocks, it is normal to see the white spaces as blocks and not as empty spaces.)

For the third puzzle, it is normal to add to an existing structure. Nobody is willing to destroy something while trying to make things better. What if they are wrong? If they added something, they can just remove it. If they broke something while removing something, now they can't add it again. (What if that corner bar is glued to the sides. If you remove it and have no glue, then you can't put it back.)
It builds on the premise that you don't know what made it work in the first place, but you are willing to trust that the original was good, to begin with, and you are just there to add something to it. Adding to it will also give you the ability to dodge complete failure, since you are only responsible for what you added, and nothing of the base structure was changed by you. Changing something about the base structure will magically make you completely responsible for it, and all the failures it had that you didn't change, suddenly become your mistakes.

You will not think about removing things when cleaning for multiple reasons. If you clean someone else's room, you are practically forbidden to remove things, unless explicitly asked for permission. (You only make that mistakes once. Unless you are an idiot or the person that lets you clean its room is an idiot) If you clean your own room, then you are busy with the cleaning aspect and don't want to deal with the questions, if you are going to use, or find a use for all that stuff. That is why many people just put those things aside. They have the illusion that they will figure it out later.

So the reason why people can solve problems with subtracting is simple. It makes far more problems than solve problems. The best way to remove something is by replacing it with something better. And when nobody is still using the old thing, then you remove it. The richest cultures are the cultures that tried to change a lot, but didn't manage to switch over everybody from the old to the new. And ended up making things worse. And the new people came around and try to remove the old again, and again, made it worse. So look at your culture and see how many new things there are with respect to old things. If your history dates back 1000 of years like the Japanse culture, then you know that nobody is removing anything. If it's like North Korea, then you know that adding is pointless as it will be removed when your back is turned. You can hear it in the language people use. There are people who talk about improving and making things better. And there are people that talk about changing things for the better or optimize their performance. (or worse: make it fit in their standard, adapt it to their way of living)

So this puzzle doesn't test your capabilities in problem serving, it just tests your culture. You can read the comments of this vid, to see which cultures are interested in this vid.

PS: This is meant as positive feedback, not negative. (see what I did there 😉)

This is an inherently flawed Puzzle, it requires you to assume things that go against your prior experience with similar puzzles without explicitely telling you the full rules. Normally in puzzles like that you are not allowed to remove pieces that are already in place. It would be like if you gave somebody a game that looked like sodoku that was unsolvable under the normal rules of Sodoku, then told them after they gave up that they were allowed to change any of the numbers you had put in... yeah technically it did not SAY they weren't allowed to do that, you are burying the lead by not giving the full rules of what they are allowed to do and what they aren't. Alot of "thought experiments" are designed in this kind of "entrapment" style where they bury the lead for the question they are asking, and therefore the obviously get the expected results, it is confirmation bias at its finest.

A better designed puzzle would have two squares one on the left side with enough green boxes to fully fill the square on the right and then the puzzle on the right , the instructions would then say "Move the boxes between the two squares so that the square on the right is symmetrical. Your goal is to move as few boxes from the left as possible." That gives you the full rules without burying the lead or giving you the answer explicitly.

0:15 — The LEGO figure instantly biased my solution, because his hair height would no longer fit underneath the structure if the single block was just removed.

Additionally, because there is an explicit cost started as associated to adding blocks in the logic puzzle, but no specification about cost for removing them, it also has the implication that the puzzle's approach is meant to be limited to achieving the result in the smallest number of additional blocks, rather than an open solution of how to approach the problem. That's because you don't state negative constraints unless they're intended to be a part of the consideration at the outset.

Essentially, the introductory premise here is really subtly biased in its language and presentation vs. a properly neutral introduction to the concept.

If you created a LEGO structure that was one block taller, and then asked, "What is the most efficient way to keep the roof from tipping if a weight was added on top of this corner?" You'd no longer be providing a bias towards additive solutions to solving the problem. Especially when it comes to cognitive bias, careful choice of language is a massive factor in establishing accurate results.
